{{Short description|Moldovan ruler (David DUCA 's father's)}} {{for multi|the American country music artist|George Ducas (singer)|the Moldovan academic and politician|Gheorghe Duca}} {{Infobox royalty | title = | name = George Ducas | image = 121 - Gheorghe Duca.jpg | caption = Ducas on a mural of the [[Cetățuia Monastery]] | succession = [[List of rulers of Moldavia|Prince of Moldavia]]
''(1st reign)'' | reign1 = 11 September 1665 – 21 May 1666 | predecessor1 = [[Eustratie Dabija]] | successor1 = [[Iliaș Alexandru]] | succession2 = [[List of rulers of Moldavia|Prince of Moldavia]]
''(2nd reign)'' | reign2 = 8 November 1668 – 10 August 1672 | predecessor2 = [[Iliaș Alexandru]] | successor2 = [[Ștefan Petriceicu]] | succession3 = [[List of rulers of Wallachia|Prince of Wallachia]] | reign3 = November/December 1674 – 29 November 1678 | predecessor3 = [[Grigore I Ghica]] | successor3 = [[Șerban Cantacuzino]] | succession4 = [[List of rulers of Moldavia|Prince of Moldavia]]
''(3rd reign)'' | reign4 = 28 November 1678 – 25 December 1683 | predecessor4 = [[Antonie Ruset]] | successor4 = [[Ștefan Petriceicu]] | succession5 = [[Ottoman Ukraine|Hetman of Ottoman Ukraine]] | reign5 = 11 February 1681 – 25 December 1683 | predecessor5 = [[Yurii Khmelnytsky]] | successor5 = Teodor Soulymenko | spouse = [[Anastasiya Dabizha]], then Dafina Doamna | issue = [[Constantine Ducas (Moldavian ruler)|Constantine Ducas]] (prince of Moldavia)
Matei
Maria (engaged to Prince [[Antioh Cantemir]])
Catrina (wife of Prince [[Ștefan Tomșa]])
Ileana (wife of chronicler [[Nicolae Costin (chronicler)|Nicolae Costin]])
Sanda
Safta
Anastasia | house = | house-type = Dynasty | father = | mother = | birth_date = ca. 1620 | birth_place = [[Ottoman Albania]] | death_date = 31 March 1685 | death_place = [[Lviv|Lwów]], Poland | burial_place = [[Cetățuia Monastery]], [[Iași]] | signature = Gheorghe Duca stamp.jpg | religion = [[Eastern Orthodox Church|Orthodox]]| }} [[Voivode]] '''George Ducas''' ([[Greek language|Greek]]: ''Γεώργιος Δούκας'', ''Geórgios Doúkas''; [[Romanian language|Romanian]]: ''Gheorghe Duca''; [[Romanian Cyrillic alphabet|old Romanian]]: ''Георге Дука;'' c. 1620 – 31 March 1685) was three times [[List of Moldavian rulers|prince]] of [[Moldavia]] (1665–1666, 1668–1672, 1678–1684), one time [[List of Wallachian rulers|prince]] of [[Wallachia]] (1674–1678) and one time Hetman of [[Ottoman Ukraine]] (1681–1683). He was married to [[Anastasiya Dabizha]], the daughter of Prince [[Eustratie Dabija]], and later to Dafina Doamna; George Ducas fathered [[Constantine Ducas (Moldavian ruler)|Constantine Ducas]]. [[File:Manastirea Cetatuia Iasi 01.JPG|thumb|Prince Gheorghe Duca built the [[Cetățuia Monastery]] in [[Iași]] (capital of the [[Principality of Moldavia]]). It was completed in 1672.]] ==First two rules in Moldavia== [[File:Mănăstirea Cetăţuia24.jpg|thumb|The fortified palace of the monastery was destined to the lodging of the Prince. It houses a typical 17th century [[Hammam|Turkish Bath]].]] Gheorghe Duca was of [[Greeks|Greek]] [[Albanians|Albanian]] origin and like many others of his generation who had migrated to the Danubian principalities he rose thanks to his links to other Albanians of high positions. In his youth, another Albanian, [[Vasile Lupu]] (voivode of Moldavia) took him to his court where Duca was raised.{{sfn|Wasiucionek|2016|p=106}} Supported by Dafina Doamna and some of the [[boyars]], he came to the throne in [[Iaşi]] after Dabija's death, but was soon ousted after his opponents appealed to the [[Ottoman Empire|Ottomans]], unjustly claiming Duca's rule was corrupt. [[File:Mănăstirea Cetăţuia5.jpg|thumb|The monastery church.]] [[File:Mănăstirea Cetăţuia42.jpg|thumb|Gheorghe Duca, his wife [[Anastasiya Dabizha|Anastasia Dabizha]] and some of their children on a mural of the church.]] He contracted large debts in order to reclaim the throne, which he managed to following [[Iliaș Alexandru]]'s rule. The policy of increased taxation led to the uprising of Mihalcea Hâncu in October 1671, crushed the next year after Ducas received [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] help. But, as Ducas failed to provide supplies needed for the [[Great Turkish War|War]] against the [[Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth]], with the [[Sultan]] [[Mehmed IV]]'s life placed in peril at the attack of [[Kamianets-Podilskyi]], the [[Ottoman Empire|Ottomans]] swiftly replaced him with [[Ștefan Petriceicu]]. [[File:Sultan Mehmed IV (2).jpg|thumb|Sultan [[Mehmed IV]], ruler of the [[Ottoman Empire]] from 1648 to 1687.]] ==Rule in Wallachia== In 1674, through the intervention of the [[Cantacuzino family|Cantacuzino]] boyars, he was awarded the throne in [[Bucharest]]; soon however, the alliance between the Cantacuzinos and Ducas crumbled, the prince being replaced by [[Șerban Cantacuzino]]. ==Last rule in Moldavia and rule in Right-bank Ukraine== [[File:Vienna Battle 1683.jpg|thumb|The [[battle of Vienna]] in 1683, by [[Frans Geffels]] (1625–1694)]] He was soon back on the Moldavian throne, following [[Antonie Ruset]] (Rosetti)'s reign. George Ducas had plans of extending his rule over [[right-bank Ukraine]], where [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] gains had started with the acquisition of [[Podolia]] in 1672. His overlord appointed him as hetman over the newly gained regions, in 1680 or 1681, after much [[bribery]] strained the Moldavian [[treasury]] as much as the request that Ducas had placed on the taxed categories that they contribute to his daughter's [[dowry]]. In 1683, Ducas joined the [[Ottoman Empire|Ottomans]] in their march at the [[Battle of Vienna]]. Helped by his absence and aware of the complete failure of the [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] plans, boyars throughout the land rebelled, following Ștefan Petriceicu's command, and welcomed the invading [[Polish people|Poles]] and [[Cossacks]]. On his way back, Ducas was captured on 25 December 1683 and sent to a prison in [[Poland]], where he died one year later. [[File:Mănăstirea Cetăţuia10.jpg|thumb|Burial of Prince Gheorghe and his daughter Maria, at the [[Cetățuia Monastery]].]] [[Image:Duca Voda.JPG|thumb|Ducas Voda, Prince of Moldavia and [[hetman]] of Ukraine, on Romanian stamps from 1941]] == Bibliography == *{{cite journal |last1=Cernovodeanu |first1=Paul |title=Ştiri privitoare la Gheorghe Ghica vodă al Moldovei ( 1658– 1659 ) şi la familia sa (I) |journal=Anuarul Institutului de Istorie și Arheologie "A.D. Xenopol." |date=1982 |volume=19 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=COe2AAAAIAAJ |publisher=Institutul de Istorie și Arheologie "A.D. Xenopol." |language=Romanian}} *{{cite book |last1=Wasiucionek |first1=Michal |editor1-last=Sariyannis |editor1-first=Marinos |title=New Trends in Ottoman Studies: Papers presented at the 20th CIÉPO Symposium Rethymno, 27 June – 1 July 2012 |date=2012 |publisher=University of Crete – Department of History and Archaeology |url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/282647065 |chapter=Ethnic solidary in the wider Ottoman Empire revisited: cins and local political elites in 17th century Moldavia and Wallachia}} *{{cite thesis |last=Wasiucionek |first=Michal |year=2016 |title=Politics and Watermelons: Cross-Border Political Networks in the Polish-Moldavian-Ottoman Context in the Seventeenth Century |url=https://cadmus.eui.eu/bitstream/handle/1814/39624/Wasiucionek_2016.pdf?isAllowed=y&sequence=1 |publisher=[[European University Institute]]}} {{S-start}} {{Succession box| before=[[Eustratie Dabija]]| title=[[List of Moldavian rulers|Prince/Voivode of Moldavia]]| years=1665–1666| after=[[Iliaș Alexandru]] }} {{Succession box| before=[[Iliaș Alexandru]]| title=[[List of Moldavian rulers|Prince/Voivode of Moldavia]]| years=1668–1672| after=[[Ştefan Petriceicu]] }} {{Succession box| before=[[Antonie Ruset]]| title=[[List of Moldavian rulers|Prince/Voivode of Moldavia]]| years=1678–1684| after=[[Ștefan Petriceicu]] }} {{Succession box| before=[[Grigore I Ghica]]| title=[[List of Wallachian rulers|Prince/Voivode of Wallachia]]| years=1673–1678| after=[[Șerban Cantacuzino]] }} {{S-end}} {{Hetmans of Ukraine}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ducas, George}} [[Category:1685 deaths]] [[Category:Monarchs of Moldavia]] [[Category:Princes of Wallachia]] [[Category:People of the Great Turkish War]] [[Category:17th-century monarchs in Europe]] [[Category:Romanian people of Albanian descent]] [[Category:Year of birth unknown]]

{{Short description|American musician}} {{BLP sources|date=July 2024}} [[File:Ducas live.jpg|thumb|George Ducas performing live in 2023]] {{Use mdy dates|date=November 2020}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = George Ducas | background = solo_singer | birth_place = [[Galveston, Texas]] | instrument = Vocals, acoustic guitar, electric guitar | genre = [[Country music|Country]] | occupation = Singer-songwriter | years_active = 1994–present | label = [[Liberty Records|Liberty]]
[[Capitol Records|Capitol Nashville]]
Loud Ranch | website = [http://www.georgeducas.com/ www.georgeducas.com] | image = | image_size = 220 }} '''George Ducas''' is an American [[country music]] singer and songwriter, and musician, known for his blend of modern-day and roots [[country music]]. He has released four studio albums: 1994's ''George Ducas'', 1997's ''Where I Stand'', 2013's ''4340'' and 2019's ''Yellow Rose Motel.'' His first two albums charted six consecutive singles on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' Hot Country Singles & Tracks (now [[Hot Country Songs]]) chart, the highest being his signature hit "[[Lipstick Promises]]" which reached No. 9 and was also a No. 1 [[CMT (American TV channel)|CMT]] video. Ducas returned to the No. 1 spot on CMT with his 2019 single "Eastwood." ==Early life== George Ducas was born in [[Galveston, Texas]] and was raised in his early years by his father Steve (an [[Exxon]] chemical engineer) and his mother Irene (a teacher and a poet) in nearby Texas City, Texas.Mitchell, Rick. "[http://www.chron.com/CDA/archives/archive.mpl?id=1994_1229284 On the brink of stardom: There's another George on country's horizon]." ''[[Houston Chronicle]]''. September 30, 1994.Hurst, Jack. "[https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/chicagotribune/access/20694022.html?dids=20694022:20694022&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Feb+5%2C+1995&author=Jack+Hurst%2C+Tribune+Country+Music+Writer.&pub=Chicago+Tribune+(pre-1997+Fulltext)&edition=&startpage=22&desc=HEAD+OF+HIS+CLASS+%60KID+FROM+VANDERBILT%27+GRADUATES+TO+NASHVILLE+WITH+HIGH+MARKS Head of his class: 'Kid from Vanderbilt' graduates to Nashville with high marks]{{dead link|date=July 2024|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}." ''[[Chicago Tribune]]''. February 5, 1995. When he was 5, his parents divorced and he spent the next five years in [[California]] with his mother, who gave him his first guitar.{{Cite web|url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/george-ducas-mn0000643105|title=George Ducas | Biography & History|website=[[AllMusic]]}} He then moved back to [[Houston]], Texas to live with his father and stepmother to attend middle school and high school. Ducas attended [[Lamar High School (Houston, Texas)|Lamar High School]] in Houston and afterward attended [[Vanderbilt University]], graduating with a degree in economics. After working six months at an [[Atlanta]] bank, he quit and relocated to [[Nashville]] to pursue a full-time career in music.Rose, Van. "Singer banks on staying power." ''The Times Leader'' (Wilkes-Barre, Pa). March 2, 1997. ==Career== Ducas performed in Nashville area clubs by night and honed his songwriting skills by day. In 1994, songwriter [[Radney Foster]] took "[[Just Call Me Lonesome (Radney Foster song)|Just Call Me Lonesome]]", a song Ducas co-wrote, into the Top Ten on the country charts.{{cite web |url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p141712/biography|pure_url=yes}} |title=George Ducas biography |access-date=November 1, 2013 |last=Ankeny |first=Jason |website=[[AllMusic]]}} Ducas' debut single "Teardrops" became a Top 40 hit on the Billboard Hot Country Songs and Country Airplay charts.{{cn|date=July 2024}} "[[Lipstick Promises]]" followed in early 1995 reaching #9 leading the way to the release of his eponymous self-titled debut album. ''George Ducas'' also produced the No. 52 "Hello Cruel World" and the No. 72 "Kisses Don't Lie". Due to a restructuring of Liberty Records, Ducas was transferred to [[Capitol Records]] Nashville. Initially Ducas' sophomore album ''Where I Stand'' was slated for release in 1996, however some record label shuffling pushed the release into the following year kicking off with the lead single "Every Time She Passes By” followed by “Long Trail Of Tears”. Ducas enlisted [[Vince Gill]] to feature his accompanying background vocals on the album.{{cn|date=July 2024}} Ducas was a songwriter for artists [[Garth Brooks]], [[Sara Evans]], [[Eli Young Band]], [[Randy Rogers Band]], [[Gary Allan]], [[The Chicks]], and [[Trisha Yearwood]].{{cn|date=July 2024}} He co-wrote - "[[The Rock: Stone Cold Country 2001|Beer Run (B Double E Double Are You In?)]]", a duet for [[Garth Brooks]] and [[George Jones]] - which received a Grammy nomination in 2009 for [[Grammy Award for Best Country Collaboration with Vocals|Best Country Collaboration with Vocals]].{{cite news|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/complete-list-of-grammy-nominees/|title=Complete List Of Grammy Nominees|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20031010122104/http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2002/01/04/entertainment/main323197.shtml|archive-date=October 10, 2003|date=January 4, 2002|access-date=March 19, 2011|url-status=live|publisher=[[CBS]]}} In 2005, Ducas and Radney Foster co-wrote the No. 1 hit "[[A Real Fine Place to Start]]" for [[Sara Evans]] which led to Ducas spending the latter half of 2007 opening shows for her.{{Cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1572308/20071018/evans_sara.jhtml|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071029204206/http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1572308/20071018/evans_sara.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=October 29, 2007|title=Sara Evans Announces Tour With Josh Turner|website=Cmt.com}} In October 2013, Ducas released ''4340'' through the newly created independent label Loud Ranch.{{cite web |url=http://www.nodepression.com/profiles/blogs/george-ducas-4340-album-review |title=Album review: George Ducas – 4340 Album |access-date=November 1, 2013 |work=No Depression}} In 2016, Ducas released the single "Party with Your Boots On" which was licensed to the [[Houston Livestock Show and Rodeo]] as their first official artist theme song on a limited term usage agreement.{{cn|date=July 2024}} Ducas’ fourth studio album ''Yellow Rose Motel'' was released in January 2020. In addition to writing and recording the album in several Nashville recording sessions throughout 2017 and 2018, Ducas also co-produced the album. The song “Eastwood”, the first of three music videos from the album, became Ducas’ second #1 CMT video and remained in the top spot for three weeks.{{cite web |url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1804630/george-ducas-makes-our-day-with-eastwood/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190403173428/http://www.cmt.com/news/1804630/george-ducas-makes-our-day-with-eastwood/|url-status=dead|archive-date=April 3, 2019|title=George Ducas Makes Our Day With Eastwood|website=Cmt.com}} In 2020, as a celebration of the 25th anniversary of his biggest hit, Ducas recorded a new version of "Lipstick Promises." American Songwriter Magazine called the new version 'a fun re-work' as "...the new version now features a little more energy as George kicked the tempo up a couple of notches. It hasn’t changed per se, it just sounds a little more like he plays it when he’s live onstage."{{cite web |url=https://americansongwriter.com/lipstick-promises-george-ducas-song-interview/|title=George Ducas Polishes Off A Commemorative Edition of Lipstick Promises|website=americansongwriter.com|date=November 5, 2020 }} In 2020, Ducas began the process of recording his new album ''Long Way From Home'', which was produced by [[Pete Anderson]] ([[Dwight Yoakam]]) and released in June of 2024.{{Cite web |title= 'Long Way from Home' - George Ducas - New Album Review|date=June 20, 2024 |url=https://rootsnrevelry.com/long-way-from-home-george-ducas/}} ==Discography== ===Studio albums=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |+List of studio albums, with release date, label, and selected chart positions shown ! scope="col" rowspan="2"| Title ! scope="col" rowspan="2"| Album details ! scope="col" colspan="2"| Peak chart

Webster |- | 1996 ! scope="row"| "Every Time She Passes By"{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qwkEAAAAMBAJ&q=%22George+Ducas%22+%22Michael+Merriman%22&pg=RA1-PA85|title=Billboard – Jun 15, 1996 – Google Books Result|date=June 15, 1996|access-date=October 30, 2010}} |- | 2015 ! scope="row"| "Party with Your Boots On" | Liz Chapman |- | 2019 ! scope="row"| "Eastwood" | Cody Villalobos |- |- | 2019 ! scope="row"| "Unlove You" | Cody Villalobos |- | 2020 ! scope="row"| "Lipstick Promises (Reboot)" | rowspan="2"| Ben Boutwell |- |} ==External links== * [https://www.georgeducas.com/ Official website of George Ducas] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ducas, George}} [[Category:1971 births]] [[Category:American alternative country singers]] [[Category:American country singer-songwriters]] [[Category:American male singer-songwriters]] [[Category:Capitol Records artists]] [[Category:Country musicians from Texas]] [[Category:Liberty Records artists]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Texas City, Texas]] [[Category:Singer-songwriters from Texas]]
